Okay here we go again... To all you Christians commenting that evolution is false or whatever:

First off, lets get this off the bat. If you don't believe evolution to be true, then you are not properly educated on it. Your so called "education" you have received on evolution sounds like the typical propaganda that would be taught in a creationist organisation. You are misrepresenting the whole concept.

Okay first let's get your terminology right. Evolution is a scientific theory. The word theory in science has a different meaning than its normal everyday use.  In science, a theory is not a guess, not a hunch. It's a well-substantiated, well-supported, well-documented explanation for our observations. It ties together all the facts about something, providing an explanation that fits all the observations and can be used to make predictions. In science, a theory is the ultimate goal, the explanation. It's as close to proven as anything in science can be. Gravity is also just a theory, and not believing in evolution doesn't make it any less real than not believing in the theory of gravity allows you to float the fuck away. It has been proven and stood the test of time for more than 150 years. It is probably one of the most well-substantiated theories out there.

Micro and Macro Evolution are ambiguous terms and are not considered scientific since they hold no form of value to the concept or theory. I challenge you to find one peer reviewed published scientific journal that uses the terms Micro and Macro Evolution and if you do, I will consider changing my stance on the matter.

There is tons of evidence for evolution:
•  We have the fossil records that show how species gradually change and evolve over time in order to adapt and survive in their ever changing environment.

•  We can physically observe evolution occurring in micro organisms. We know that the more complex the species, the longer it takes for evolution to change the species to such a notable level that it is can be considered an entirely different species from what it was originally. Noticeable evolution in a complex species does not happen over one or even 10 generations, it happens over thousands of generations of natural selection, survival of the fittest and the rare beneficial genetic mutation.

•  We humans are losing our wisdom teeth and our jaws are shrinking. Even though we have changed the recipe for evolution to happen in our own species by allowing the weak to survive and changing our views of natural selection from mere reproduction purposes to more complex and diverse traits, doesn't mean that we have stopped evolving. We are just evolving based on the environment we are in which is artificial at best. It's interesting if you think about it a bit.

•  We can even see how different races of human beings adapted to suit their environments. Black people have dark skin and less hair because of the intense heat in Africa and white people have more hair and lighter skin so they can absorb more Vitamin D from the sun in the cold climates in Europe. Creation does not explain this.

•  Look at dogs. Dogs are a prime example of evolution being manipulated by man in order to create a separate species from the wolf and other canines who would rather be a companion to man instead of adapting to survive on its own. We messed with evolution thousands of years before we even knew what it was. Dogs are a man made species completely separate from the wolf. Humanity witnessed the wolf change into the dog. We made the dog. That is evolution. We have seen it with out own goddamn eyes.

All these little facts and pieces of information and much more come together to form the theory of evolution. That is all it really is. It's an explanation of how life came to be the way it is today from the moment it came into existence, nothing else, and it's the best explanation we have and has since it has since its induction, only grown stronger . Evolution doesn't explain the origin of life or where life came from, that is a different topic, evolution merely explains what happened a split second after that. We don't know exactly how life came into existence, but that doesn't mean that we should just throw our hands in the air and scream "GOD DID IT!". We need to use science, logic and reasoning to figure it out and we will figure it out soon. Science is moving faster than it ever has and one day we will know.

The problem with this though is that it disproves the creation story from the bible and if the creation story is not true, then the story of Jesus would have been pointless and without Jesus, Christianity kind of falls apart. That is why you either have liberal moderate Christians who kind of admit that evolution makes more sense but they still find a way to wriggle god in there somewhere and disregard the creation story as metaphorical for evolution and thereby keeping their religion relevant or the fundamental conservative christian who either distorts evolution with propaganda and dismisses all scientific evidence for it, or just blatantly keeps themselves ignorant on the subject by only reading material on it via christian platforms instead of legitimate scientific forums.

Hopefully now you will be more educated on what evolution actually is and hopefully you will not choose to just blatantly ignore all the facts I stated that prove it to be true. Evolution is a collective name given to all these facts and phenomenon happening in our physical world. Anyone who says different doesn't know what evolution is or has been greatly misled.﻿

When there is no real evidence, evolutionary scientists simply make assumptions.
If evolution were true, then where is the evidence of different types of animals now "evolving" into other types? Where is the evidence of cats, dogs and horses gradually turning into something else? We do see changes within species, but we do not see any changes into other species. And, as mentioned, we see no evidence of gradual change in the fossil record either. Yet evolutionists continue to assume that transitional forms must have existed.

Evolution is still called a theory—a possible explanation or assumption—because it is not testable according to the scientific method, as this would require thousands or millions of years. Evolutionists will counter that a theory is not a mere hypothesis but is a widely affirmed intellectual construct that generally appears to fit all the facts. Yet evolution in no way fits all the facts available. Evidence does not support it—and in many respects runs counter to it.

One of the best ways to show that the earth is not "billions of years old" is to look at the sun.

We are all aware that the sun is burning. What you may not have thought of though, is that it can not burn forever. Though the sun does oscillate, it is also rapidly decreasing in size and mass.

For the last 300 years Boyal Observatory in England has been keeping records of the suns diameter.

They have carefully recorded the rate the sun is shrinking. They have determined that the sun is shrinking at a rate of 5 feet per hour. At this rate, the sun would have been twice its present radius only one million years ago. The farther you go back in time, the larger the sun would have been. This is true even though the rate of shrinkage may not have always been the same. In fact in the past, the sun would have burned faster than it does today.

"The shrinkage rate centuries ago would be determined by the balance of the solar forces. Since the potential energy of a homogeneous spherical sun varies inversely with the solar radius, the rate of shrinkage would have been greater in the past than it is now".

This means that today’s rate of shrinkage (5 feet per hour) was faster years ago. Perhaps at the rate of 10 or 20 feet per hour.

The sun would have been big enough to touch the earth only 20 million years ago. Evolutionists claim the earth is 4 BILLION years old. You can see why this is impossible.

If the earth was Billions of years old, then the earth would have been destroyed by the sun.

Isn't it obvious to you that you are confusing scientific facts with what humans make of them? For example, science can tell us that race x is generally smarter than race y, but to say that therefore y is INFERIOR to x, you'd have to adopt some political or social theory, because scientifically you cannot make such judgments. And to say that you should not believe in Darwinism, because ideologies based on it are bad (which I agree with) have NOTHING to do with the scientific fact of evolution.

Finally, your biggest error here seems to be the implication that belief in evolution goes along with social Darwinism. It does not. Many non-theists endorse what is called "secular humanism", which is the complete opposite of the ideology that you are trying to associate evolution with.

That is all pure nonsense. What you are talking about is not evolution, but social Darwinism. One is a morally neutral naturally occurring process, while the other is a human construct, an ideology. And how does it even matter what Darwin's social and political views were? That all seems to be completely irrelevant. It's like saying that to believe in the big bang theory you have to become a Christian, because Lemaître, the first person to propose it, was a priest. That's just a non-sequitur.

This may need an additional box as well. Here is Part 1: I'm in full support of the reality of micro-evolution (adaptions within already existing geno-types). But my skepticism of macro-evolution is way beyond mild. Your question--if I'm understanding it correctly--is a good one. Suppose you observe the way erosion, rock slides, weather, etc.. has made various patterns in rock formations. These patterns can be improbable and complex, but nothing necessarily that exhibits design. See Part 2.

Beyond the flagellum, there are 100s of additional protein machines in the cell. The mathematical odds against natural processes forming cells is excruciating, Then add the intricacy,  functionality, and hierarchy of information with these cells and we're forced by experience and reason to say that design is the best explanation. And that's just 1 cell. Life going beyond that gets even worse for nature to pull off. Even with favorable mutations, the odds against remain statistically impossible.

The previous stats present a staggeringly high unlikelihood that 1 protein molecule would form randomly. The bacterial flagellum, for example,has 30 proteins with hundreds of amino acids in their respective chains. We saw the statistical impossibility for the formation of one protein. How much more impossible is it for natural processes to build this molecular machine? Further, these proteins are arrayed in such a way that we observe a functional motor. Design is the most reasonable inference

It may take a couple of boxes, but here it is: The mathematical odds against random processes being able to put together cellular machinery, cells, and the diversity of life beyond that, remains astronomically unfavorable. In fact, the odds of getting one simple protein molecule of 100 amino acids by natural processes, is one chance in 10 to the 130th power. This goes beyond the probabilistic resources of the universe, and thereby, dwarfs the lottery ticket odds. And that's just one protein.

There's a lot of evidence on the origin of mitochondria. Mitochondria look like bacteria living inside each of our cells: their DNA sequences are similar to bacteria, they replicate separately from the cell, and they have their own cell membrane that has characteristically bacterial proteins in it. It sounds bizarre, but the process (endosymbiosis) is well-known: corals engulf photosynthetic algae that live inside their cells, and that give them color and energy. Look it up - it's interesting!

And I'll give you credit for being open-minded. Gene duplication is pretty common; in humans, it's been estimated at 25 genes per person, and it's the most commonly cited mechanism for new information. The genetic mechanism for growth is actually well understood. A gene called Insulin-like growth factor 1 signals bone and muscle cells to divide. What is this supposed to prove Just because Darwin was right about random mutation + natural selection doesn't mean he was right about everything else. Sure, he may have been a racist. That doesn't mean that he didn't have the correct theory of evolution.

Also, Darwin didn't know about DNA and all of that. That's why biologists follow Neo-Darwinistic theories which add in all the things that weren't known in Darwin's time, including horizontal gene transfer. But Darwin still had the right idea.

Furthermore, DNA absorbs UV radiation very strongly. That extra energy has to go somewhere, so new molecular bonds form and mutate the DNA, often causing skin cancer. The extra color pigment in darker skin (often from sunnier climates) absorbs the UV light so that it doesn't reach the DNA. It has nothing to do with heat.  Besides which, dark colors absorbs MORE infrared radiation (A.K.A. heat), just like it absorbs more light. Hence the dark color of dark things.

There is no such thing as "further evolved"--that is merely an exceedingly anthropocentric point of view. Everything evolves to fit its own niche.  Sharks may "only" be fish, but they fit their lifestyle perfectly and have not needed to change in millions of years.

Examples of symbolic codes include music, blueprints, languages like English and Chinese, computer programs, and yes, DNA.  The essential distinction is the difference between a pattern and a code.   Chaos can produce patterns, but it has never been shown to produce codes or symbols.  Codes and symbols store information, which is not a property of matter and energy alone.  Information itself is a separate entity on par with matter and energy.

Patterns occur naturally – no help required from a ‘designer’. Many patterns occur in nature without the help of a designer – snowflakes, tornados, hurricanes, sand dunes, stalactites, rivers and ocean waves.  These patterns are the natural result of what scientists categorize as chaos and fractals.  Codes, however, do not occur without a designer.....

*** Where does redundancy come from? If you take a word out, you can fill it in from the context. Your mind can fill in the difference. Most of you never thought of this, but in when you’re on the internet or getting and receiving emails there’s a whole collection of mechanisms that are put in the communication back and forth to ensure that errors are corrected before they get to you. This is common to almost all languages. ###

Regardless of what kind of communication we are talking about those four things are present in that communication. Alphabet, grammar, meaning and intent. And nearly all languages have error correction or redundancy. English is about 50% redundant, which means if you’re talking on your cell phone and its cutting in and out and in and out, if you can hear every word you can still pretty much figure out what’s being said. ### And then it has these four characteristics; it has an alphabet, it has grammar, it has meaning, and it has intent. Every language has those four things. The genetic code contained within DNA is the epitome of a code. Here is an example of how it works: Nucleotides > mRNA > Proteins: Base pairs are grouped into codons and encoded (transcribed) into messenger RNA,  then decoded (translated) by the ribosomes into proteins. The DNA symbol unit is a nucleotide, forming a 4 letter alphabet of Adenine, Cytosine, Guanine, or Thymine. Each base pair contains k = 2 bits of information. A character consists of n = 3 symbol units.--

Sub-atomic particles "pop" in and out of existence all the time in empty space. They come in the form of a particle and an anti-particle, so they typically self annihilate and go largely unnoticed. Sometimes, they don't. For example, if they pop in on the edge of a black hole, only one gets sucked in. this results in a particle being "created" and flying away from the black hole. We call this "Hawking Radiation".

So, yes, something can come from nothing, it happens literally all of the time.

My biology teacher loves this.

It all comes down to randomness, but not chance. The entire planet was covered in these chemicals, subject to lightning, magma, storms, tectonic forces and constant heat and movement. That it only takes a few pieces to create a replicating structure and there were countless chemical reactions going on all over the planet, it was only inevitable that it would happen. And apparently it happened pretty quick, because life appears pretty much simultaneously with liquid oceans in the fossil record.

The most difficult part is the ribosome, which is a relatively complex machine, but it only takes a few before they start pumping out amino acid chains into proteins and building new organelles and more complex organelles and proteins that start to the process of biogeneis and the evolution of life. In reality, it's very likely that a few ribosomes started building amino acid chains filling primordial pools with organic material which, eventually lead to a simple organism that could replicate.

In the early earth conditions, shortly after it cooled enough to have liquid oceans, the atmosphere and oceans were full of chemicals that do not appear naturally on earth anymore and heat and pressure conditions that were a consequence of a volatile cooling earth. Through random combination in those conditions, before long, some of those chemicals formed compounds that are necessary to cellular life. All it takes to get started is a membrane (the easiest to get), a simple ribosome and rna.

You seem to be having trouble understanding what evolution is.  Evolution is a process of change in a whole species, not an individual, that happens via many hundreds of thousands of generations of reproduction, random mutation, and survival of the fittest members of that species to reproduce again.  Evolution has nothing whatever to do with the idea of an individual animal changing somehow (a process that does not occur, and never has).

Mutation is a CHANGE in current information.  Now, there are things called extrons (also know as "junk" DNA) within a genome.  This because the code for a protein begins with a specific "start" codon (usually ATG) and end with an "end" codon.  Anything in between is not used to create a protein.  However, if a mutation occurs that creates a new "start" codon (could even be a single base pair), that creates an entirely new protein.  A new protein from DNA that previously did nothing.

"At best, that's de-evolution, not evolution." I've already argued that "devolution" is at best a subset of evolution, and arguably is a non-sensical value judgement.

"While the vast majority of mutations cause very harmful or catastrophic affects." This is exactly what evolution is. If you believe in these mutations but not in evolution, I can only assume you have an odd definition of what evolution is?

"How can the loss of information promote evolution when that loos of information can never be regained?" I don't see how information cannot be regained. Consider, organism with geneset A creates offspring with geneset A-x (a small change). There's nothing that says organism A-x can't evolve to add x back, returning to geneset A. Do you follow?

And evolution does not require MORE information, just different information. Simpler is often better, but it's certainly different.

"Really, how can death promote evolution?" Are you thinking of macro-evolution? Evolution is about change, but not all changes will survive. Evolutionary dead ends are a necessary part of the theory: if many changes are needed to find one that's better and which prospers, there therefore must be many that don't. It's all part of evolution.

It is widely debated how the first cell came to be as it did happen billions of years ago.  Most evidence points to inorganic molecules and atoms bonding and forming organic molecules (proteins, lipids, DNA, etc.) in a primordial "soup".  These organic molecules later bind together to form simple parts and then combine to form prokaryotic cells (bacteria).  Later on the symbiotic relationship of multiple prokaryotes leads to the formation of eukaryotic cells (those with a nucleus and organelles)

For a more detailed explanation what the difference between "law" and "theory" is. Gravity would be both a law and theory. The law of gravity would be that if you drop an object, it will fall to the ground. But for an explanation why, it would be the theory of gravity that Earth's mass causes gravity that makes the object fall to the ground.

Both the law of gravity and the theory of gravity would be considered facts. "Law" is NOT some sort of upgrade from "theory".

People seriously have a misunderstanding of scientific terms. Scientific term of "law" is not some sort of upgrade from "theory". The two terms are unrelated. A scientific law is a description of an observed phenomenon but it cannot and does not explain why. Any scientific explanation of an observed phenomenon, even if 100% true, would be called a theory and cannot ever be called "law". This is why even though evolution and general relativity are considered facts, they can't ever be called laws.
